author: ddlezu01
title: Theatre For Change
description: No one is currently using Theatre in Education to engage and inspire the young generation to understand Cardano Blockchain Technology.

f6_assessments.q0: The alignment with the challenge setting is not total - the "multimedia" video element that is the core of this challenge is there, but it feels a little "tacked on" to what is, in concept, basically a live TIE (Theatre in Education) project. I don't believe this proposal will provide the "bridge" between traditional film/TV media and "new media" that the challenge setting talks about; in fact, if anything, it misses an opportunity to put money and time into building professional connections between the videographers and the theatre artists involved, which is something that it could have done. I also think it's very unlikely that the proposal will communicate a message which the "national media and TV stations" will pick up (as stated in the challenge setting), since there are no resources or time given to trying to make this happen. However, maybe all this is a shortcoming of the challenge setting itself, and perhaps the challenge is a little too restrictive in its focus on national impact and bridges between different types of media. Since this proposal will be educative, and will produce creative content, I feel it's broadly in the spirit of the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
Unfortunately, I can't agree that this proposal is feasible as it stands. The proposal doesn’t seem to show sufficient awareness of the practicalities of getting a TIE production performed in a school. As someone who has worked in TIE in 3 countries, I know it’s extremely rare that you just contact a school with an offer, and they agree. There is usually a need for several weeks of building relationships with teachers and head teachers; discussion of practicalities; explaining how your work is curriculum-linked and what the school will gain from bringing you in; and managing dates and times, legalities such as public liability insurance and child protection (yes, it’s true that with an audience age range of 15-21, some of the young people involved are technically adults – but many are not) and so on. There is a small budget element for “Team + coordination” costed in the proposal that might cover this engagement and project management, but it is not accounted for in terms of time – the project will simply identify 6 schools and “inform” them, and perform at two of them that same month. This also allows very little time for scriptwriting and rehearsal.

Also, I think it is over-ambitious to work with 6 schools and expect to onboard 1,000 people into Cardano. That equates to over 150 people per school. Onboarding (e.g. helping people set up a wallet, etc) will almost certainly require some 1-2-1 support for the audience members, and the team doesn't seem to be big enough to do this for 150 people per performance; possibly, they pan to do it after the performance by going back in to the school, but this is not clear, and if it is the case it’s not clearly budgeted for in terms of money or time. Also it’s not clear who the performers will be, and how they will gain the knowledge needed to help people onboard. Are the performers already in the Cardano ecosystem? If so, the project plan should explain this. Or will they need to be trained themselves, so that they can onboard audience members? If so, that training process should be resourced. 

Leading on from this, the proposal says that a measure of success will be “Teachers being familiar with and can introduce Cardano Blockchain Technology to new students” – but there is no training or support offered for teachers to do this, and no consideration of how it might sit within the curriculum. In most countries, teachers are overworked, overstretched, and find it already difficult to cover the curriculum they need to cover; so it feels unfeasible to ask them to additionally support the onboarding of students to Cardano without training or support, and without helping them link it to the learning they are supposed to deliver. I think if the proposal had at least looked at connecting this TIE program with the local curriculum – which I can imagine multiple ways to do – the proposal would have been much more feasible. 

There is also a feasibility issue for me with the age range being covered. Ages 15-21 is a very wide range, and young people’s lives, their capacity, and their interests change dramatically between these ages. It feels like a very big ask to create a TIE program that will appeal across this whole age range – I would have felt it was more feasible if the proposers had narrowed down the ages they want to reach. Leading on from this point – best practice in TIE would involve doing at least a little research or engagement with potential audiences in advance of scriptwriting, and having their input into what they are interested in and how they would want to see the themes presented. The proposal does not mention whether any of the team currently work with or have any links with young people, which might give them this kind of background knowledge in an informal way; but if they do, then it would have been great to explain that in the proposal, so that we know that the performances will be pitched right and will be engaging to the young people watching. But from the information given it seems that nobody involved does have this knowledge, which from my experience is a major contribution to the feasibility or success of a TIE program.
Although the pay for the scriptwriter seems OK in terms of Ghana’s average wage, I would like to see more clarity around the performers’ pay. How many performers does the figure cover?  Without this, we can’t tell if it’s a reasonable amount per performer. I’d also like to see it broken down a bit more, so we can see how much of the performers’ work  is to be actual performing, how much is rehearsal, how much is post-performance engagement, evaluation with the audience, etc. This would tell us whether all the needed elements are appropriately costed.

Also - the proposers say "we shall convey our message in the language in which the target audience understands best" but there is no budget given for translation, and there is only one scriptwriter, who is not being paid enough to create multiple versions in different languages; so I’d value some more information about how this will be achieved.

It’s also concerning to me that the proposal subscribes to and references the concept of "learning styles", a non-evidence-based myth that educators have repeatedly debunked, but which is oddly persistent and keeps on being used. (For some background to this issue, see for example https://go.gale.com/ps/i.do?id=GALE%7CA628405045&sid=googleScholar&v=2.1&it=r&linkaccess=abs&issn=15399664&p=AONE&sw=w&userGroupName=anon%7E1a955a2  or https://digest.bps.org.uk/2021/02/04/the-learning-styles-myth-is-still-prevalent-among-educators-and-it-shows-no-sign-of-going-away/  or https://leftypol.org/tech/src/1627217656435.pdf/, or just Google “learning styles myth” for multiple references. The proposal basing its methods on something widely discredited, has a negative impact on how I see its feasibility, as it suggests the proposal team are not well informed about best practice in learning.) 

Also, as someone who has worked widely in Theatre In Education, I can say it's concerning to see the proposer talk about TIE being used to "make" students do something (A quote from the proposal reads "Live theatre is a powerful way to attract students’ attention and... make them adopt Cardano Blockchain Technology easily”). This approach is completely contrary to best practice in TIE, which is meant to stimulate students to develop critical thinking and draw their own conclusions, and definitely not to “make” them do this or that. Yes, this could just be a slip of the keyboard – but coupled with all the other unfeasibilities in the project plan, it gives me pause. 

I realise I’ve written an essay here – that’s because although I would love to support this proposal, and think using TIE in this context is a good concept, unfortunately I don’t think the proposal is well thought out or likely to be implemented successfully, and I wanted to explain properly why not.
f6_assessments.q2: The audit metrics given are measurable, and are clear in terms of timescale and what will be measured, so it feels reasonably likely that the project can be audited. However, for me, these metrics do raise questions about what “onboarding” means. Does it just mean young people creating a wallet (and maybe even delegating that wallet to a stakepool) that they will then never look at again? The “what does success look like” section hints at more meaningful onboarding with its mention of students using blockchain technology for their final year projects; but I would ideally like to have seen a little more audit of medium-term outcomes. So although the project is certainly auditable in the very short term (counting numbers who “sign up” immediately post-performance), I would love to have seen more clarity on what successful onboarding would look like, and the inclusion of one or two more longterm success metrics for those onboarded.
f6_assessments.reply: Feasibility: As we mention in the proposal the team members are highly integrated into the theatre space: "Samuel N. Lamptey is the projects coordinator for a local Community based theatre group that are having a major positive impact in their society." in addition, the assesor mentions that the team doesn't seem capable of providing the 1-2-1 support needed to onboard members, however the proposal specifically mentions the Wada Ghana team that will be backing this project to support the onboarding of new members. In regards to the age range the assesor is neglecting to consider the local context in Ghana where 15-21 year olds do sit in a similar age range in terms of even potentially being in the same class in school. In many countries in Africa, Ghana included, it is more common than in the US for example for students to be held back  (major difference from US system-- where we are used to associating age and grade in school very predictably), therefore it is not as uncommon to have a wider range of ages in different school classes, which explains the age range further.

f6_assessments.q0: This is a fascinating concept, and a fascinating addition to the challenge.  Theater brings a unique element among the arts to the expression of ideas:  immediacy.  It is action, and the audience is a part of it.  When the performer and the work are in concert it has the effect of impressing upon the viewer a sense of "THIS...NOW", a very visceral, lived experience.  It would be fascinating to see such an experiment try to represent and express Cardano and the principles underlying it, of decentralized governance, self sovereign identity.  It is an exciting prospect to think about.  While not asking for a broadway performance running for weeks and being seen by thousands, the scope and reach of the proposed project isn't anything to shrug at:  they expect to reach 2000 participants.  My only question regards a clarification.  They expect to do 2 shows in 2 schools.  In the proposal they mention secondary schools twice and second-cycle students once.  The first is grade school students, the latter is higher education students, typically masters or graduate students.  The difference seems significant to me as to the intended audience.  Also, I have some concern about the proposed focus of the play, in terms of trying to explain concepts like SPOs and NFTs.  As long as there is a rooting of these concepts in human needs and nature, I'll be happy.  If it is just an acted out wiki...much less appealing.
f6_assessments.q1: The team looks eminently qualified by experience and schooling, and they have included a list of the jobs needed outside of their scope.  All the budget items seem in line for a small scale theater performance, split evenly between technical, project management, and the "talent".  The issue of which audiences they are performing for come up, as their may be venue cost considerations (and that these are not included tilts me toward thinking they mean secondary students, where the venue would likely be free).  The delivery timeline includes one month for the acting out of both performances, which seems adequate.  If it is missing anything in this regard, it is a few more implementable details on the performance itself, such as expected length.
f6_assessments.q2: It is good the timeline isn't too long on this, because it is high on qualitative content, less so the measurable stuff that fits in the progress reports.  Delivery of a script is an obvious start, and the logistical roadmap for the two showings to lay out the movement of people and material.  As an opensource project, others will be able to build off of the script to refine it for other languages and cultures, which is a big bonus.  Once the shows are finished, the included attendance and exposure they get on social media and posting of the video should be able to capture the impact for the final report.  An online community group for providing support inspiration and oversight would be a welcome addition to help with staying up to date on the project.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal fully satisfies the challenge's requirements, as it proposes to employ theatre in education to promote and raise awareness of Cardano Blockchain Technology in senior high schools, but it is unclear in which country, town, or place the project would be performed or carried out. The proposer stated that they aim to conduct six theatre performances in six different Second Cycle Schools for over 1000 students, but did not specify which nations or places will benefit from this brilliant concept to raise Cardano awareness. The proposal is an incredible attempt to significantly impact the Cardano/Catalyst ecosystem in the second cycle by increasing blockchain technology awareness through Theatre in Education. Students, in my opinion, are an excellent source of knowledge dissemination and are always open to new experiences.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal includes a list of team members as well as a summary or description of their background. The team appears to be well prepared and qualified to do the project, however, it would have been great if they could have provided us with their Linkedin profiles or any other profiles where we could learn more about each of them. It's even more intriguing the team is more interested in establishing Cardano blockchain roots in Africa by proposing to continue an existing initiative and create a platform to reach out to Senior High School students. The proposal also includes information on how they intend to complete the project. It provides a detailed plan and timeline for project completion, and their goals appear to be attainable. The budget is clearly allocated, with a detailed breakdown of how the project will be implemented. The proposer mentioned a language barrier as the challenge or risk associated with the successful completion of this project. They went on to devise methods or solutions to mitigate such risk. Based on the assessments above, I strongly believe that this project will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal lays out a road map with milestones and a timeline for attaining the project's aim. It states that in three months, it will perform six theatre performances at six different second-cycle schools for over 1000 students. The information provided and the key metrics mentioned in the proposal are sufficient for a complete audit of the project's progress at the end of the timetable. As a result, there is a good probability of raising Cardano blockchain awareness and grabbing students' attention in order to encourage them to adopt blockchain technology and keep them interested. Overall, this proposal has provided enough information to judge the progress toward its stated objectives.

f6_assessments.q0:
I think it is an unusual approach on Multimedia outreach, which can be very positive for the Cardano ecosystem. It provides the chance to test and explore an art form that is usually seen as distant from the technology world. At the same time, it will bring local youth closer to the Cardano community because of the more personal contact. Therefore, it is worth exploring how local theatre might impact the Cardano ecosystem.
However, I am not completely sure it fits the challenge. The challenge demands a more global approach, not so local, so it can reach a wider audience. The proposal mentions that 6 recordings will be uploaded for educational puporses, but since the social network environment is so competitive nowadays, simply recording and uploading doesn't feel like it is enough to have a digital impact. Recording the plays and uploading them feels like social media is an afterthought, when the challenge is about multimedia content.
In my opinion, the project would benefit for a more careful look on social media. They could film scenes specifically for social media, both to educate those who will not be in the plays, but to also make the ones who will be there, interested. Keeping young people focused is a challenge nowadays, so reaching out to them before the plays take place, can make them excited about it. A more structured marketing strategy for social media could make the project have a bigger reach.
f6_assessments.q1:
While the team seems very capable of executing the plays, I think there should be someone who would cover the technology aspect of it. Considering it is not easy to explain a technology through theatre, I think the team could be a bit more balanced, with people who will conrtibute with the technology perspective. I would also like to know more about their background, with links that would help me understand about their skills.
The roadmap seems to be well thought, but I would like to know how they came up with the number of 1000 students and teacher impacted. 
Since this project is heavenly dependant on local communities, I believe there could be more details on where the plays would take place and who are the actors in that community that would help the execution.
The budget seems very feasble, though it could gain from a little more detail when it comes to Marketing, Partnerships, and Promotions.
f6_assessments.q2:
I believe the KPI are aligned with the project's goal and it is very consistent. Howerver, There could be more data driven metrics, with more exact number that could help understand the impact by the end of the 3 month period. 
Where it is written "the number of Teachers and Students", there could be an estimate of how many teacher and students would be considered the ideal result. The other KPIs could also be more detailed.
f6_assessments.reply: Auditability: We have laid out specific metrics that we seek to reach such as number of performances, and total number of students reached. The other metrics we mention are also things we can track but as the assesor pointed out we have not attached specific numbers. I think the score of 2 doesn't match the review because we did provide some specific KPIs and listed other general metrics that we will track.
